item.title: Database Transactions
item.description: ACID and BASE: Database Transactions Following a chemistry analogy, we can measure a pH of a database where: ACID databases is for applications that need consistency and reliability BASE databases is for applications that need availability, flexibility and scalability ACID is an acronym that refers to 4 properties a transaction should uphold for reliability of data: Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability

item.title: Databases
item.description: Central system where data is stored and searched through [[Relational Databases]] [[Non-relational Databases]]

item.title: Non-relational Databases
item.description: Data management system where there is no relational schema, also called No-SQL databases Key-value databases Each record has a key with some data associated to it (in any format) Document databases Key-value database where value is a JSON document Column family databases Store data in rows and columns, where columns can be grouped into column-families For example, Customer family might have Name column, Address column etc.

item.title: Relational Databases
item.description: Store and query structured data which is stored in tables that represent entities Each instance of an entity is assigned a unique identifier called primary key Normalized databases: referencing entities with their primary key, allows for no duplicate data values Use SQL to manage and query database

item.title: Transactional Data Processing
item.description: Record transactions that capture business events a company wants to track Think of financial transactions: a bank would capture when money is deposited or taken out.
